attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
•    A physical stock count was conducted on 11th June 2025. The exercise aimed to confirm the accuracy of inventory balances in the SAP system and to evaluate the strength of internal control procedures surrounding inventory handling and recording at the branch.
•    A few discrepancies in the inventory records were observed as illustrated below:
a)    Bread stock had a cumulative surplus of 12 loaves,
b)    Polybags had a shortfall of 268 pieces,
c)    White flour had a deficit of 3.94kgs,
d)    Utto had a positive variance of 3.05 litres,
e)    Other stock items had minimal variation as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management to track product yield closely and ensure adherence to set dividing ranges to maintain consistent inventory levels and reduce unexplained surpluses or shortages.
attributes.effect:
•    Repeated variances, even if small, could point to systemic weaknesses in inventory tracking or staff non-compliance with stock management procedures.
•    Unexplained surpluses may suggest issues with recording procedures, while shortages could indicate loss through pilferage, wastage, or poor handling.
•    Though crate controls are currently effective, continued oversight is necessary to maintain integrity.

value:
•    We will continue monitoring Utto consumption closely to determine whether any corrections or adjustments are needed.
•    I will personally follow up on this matter and put in place measures to reduce the differences or inconsistencies in polybag usage.
•    I will also keep track of the product yield and ensure the dividing ranges are followed correctly.

•    I will ensure that stock takes are done shift-wise to minimize variations.
•    I will also enforce proper handover procedures among supervisors.
•    Polybag variance is primarily caused by remixing issues and production planning, as well as poor recording of the mixing chart. The main objective is to train supervisors on accurately recording the mixing chart.

•    In the prior audit report dated 2nd May 2025 stock take reveled the following:
a)    Polybags +484 Pieces.
b)    Bread stock had a positive variance of 6 Loaves.
c)    White flour had a variance of +3.753kgs,
d)    All other materials had negligible variations.
e)    Crates had a variance of +4 crates.
A physical count was done to compare recorded vs. actual stock of key raw materials and finished goods. Variances were observed in polybags, flour and bread loaves.
Minor variances suggest weak controls in documentation and stock handling. Enhanced tracking and shift-based stock takes were recommended.
Operations/Production Department
To verify the accuracy of inventory balances in SAP and assess the effectiveness of internal stock control measures.

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit of the mixing chart and mixing chart summary was conducted over a 31-day period (12th May to 11th June 2025) to evaluate production efficiency, resource utilization (specifically Utto consumption) and compliance with the Bill of Materials (BOM) and quality standards. 
•    The analysis revealed the following:
a)    Utto consumption stood at 100%.
b)    The average yield was 191.01 loaves per bag.
c)    Average production was 81 bags per day, this represents 93.51% of the set target of 81 bags.
d)    There were 300 remixes for the period audited.
•    Below is a summary of the audit finding:
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should liaise with KAF in order to implement a preventive maintenance schedule for critical equipment like the oven to reduce unexpected breakdowns.

•    Branch management should always consider operational adjustments (e.g., shift planning, to improve daily output consistency and recover production losses caused by technical issues
attributes.effect:
•    Although yield and Utto consumption were within acceptable limits, the production shortfall (6.49%) indicates that production targets were not fully met, partly due to operational disruptions such as oven breakdowns.
•    Delays in equipment repair, despite timely communication, may point to a gap in maintenance response from the KAF

value:
•    We had instances of oven breakdown which had a significant negative impact on the day’s production output, causing the branch to fall short of its production targets.

•    Communication was done on time but there were slow responses from the KAF

•    This is mainly caused by regular breakdowns.
•    KAF should also improve on immediately taking action upon any breakdown.

•    In the Prior Audit, audit findings were as follows: 
a)    Average production was 79.39 bags equivalent to 98% of the set target of 81 bags.
b)    Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
c)    The average yield was 191.04 loaves per bag.
d)    There were 1,357 cases of remixes for the period.
Previous
Utto usage and daily flour bag production were analyzed against set targets over a 31-day period. Production fell slightly short of target due to oven breakdowns.
Operational disruptions affected output. Preventive maintenance and improved shift planning were recommended
Operations/Production Department
To assess production efficiency, particularly yield and resource utilization, against the Bill of Materials.

attributes.title: Cash Verification.
attributes.description:
•    As part of our routine checks, a cash verification was carried out to confirm that the physical cash on hand matched the recorded cash balance in the cash flow records. This was also intended to assess the effectiveness of cash handling and management controls.
•    Findings were as illustrated below,

.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should maintain the existing cash control.
attributes.effect: •    Cash management controls are generally effective

value: •    Controls in place are generally effective and thus we shall maintain.
•    Controls in place are generally effective and thus we shall maintain

•    In prior audit, there was nil variance between cashflow amount and cash at hand.
•    However, there were two pending IOus, of Ksh.7,000.00. (Albert Okoth date 22.03.25 for meals, Ramadhan Ksh.5,000.00 for construction site inspection)
Previous
Cash verification on 12th June 2025 showed that records tallied exactly with physical cash.
Controls are effective. Branch advised to maintain current controls
Finance Department
To ensure physical cash on hand matches the recorded balances and to evaluate cash handling controls.

attributes.title: Bread weight analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A spot check on the weights of packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market was conducted on 12th June 2025 to verify if the bread weight was compliant with the KEBS standard weight.
•    The results showed mixed compliance across different bread varieties:
a)    The 200g Ml samples recorded the highest non-compliance, with 38% of the loaves falling below the required weight.
b)    The 400g Bw (Brown Wheat) and 400g Long varieties also reflected adverse underweight percentages, with 33% and 31% of loaves respectively being underweight.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure strict adherence to the required dough and bread weight standards by conducting regular follow-ups, monitoring weighing procedures, and enforcing compliance among production and packing staff
attributes.effect:
•    Regular distribution of underweight products can lead to customer complaints, loss of trust and damage to the brand’s image 
•    Overweight loaves may result in excess ingredient use, increasing production costs unnecessarily or even affecting other variety weight directly
•    Failure to meet KEBS weight standards could lead to regulatory penalties, reputational damage, and potential financial losses.

value:
•    I will closely monitor the dividing range and implement proper rotation during slicing to prevent overcooling, particularly for the Mini Loaf and Grand A varieties.
•    Additionally, I will focus on optimizing dividing accuracy and yield to minimize instances of overweight loaves.

•    Supervisors should follow up on the slicing of 200g and 400g long in good time to avoid weigh loss during the cooling process.
•    There will be regular spot check on checking weights of packed and dough weights.

•    The previous audit report dated 2nd May 2025; underweights percentage noted were as follows:
a)    400g -41%,
b)    600g Bw- 70%,
c)    800g-38%,
d)    800g Bw-22%
Previous
Sampled weights of different bread varieties revealed some underweight issues, especially for 200g and 400g loaves.
Weight non-compliance could damage brand reputation. Closer monitoring of slicing and dividing processes is essential.
Operations/Production Department
To verify if bread varieties meet Kenya Bureau of Standards (KEBS) weight requirements and branch weight standards

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An in-depth analysis was conducted to assess the levels of bread damage arising from both production defects and market-related issues during the period from 12th May 2025 to 11th June 2025. The objective was to determine whether the branch was adhering to the established quality control standards.
•    We noted the following:
a)    Production damages amounted to 0.204% of the total production volume, which is slightly above the acceptable KPI limit of 0.20%. Although the deviation is minor, it indicates a need for closer monitoring of production processes to prevent a further increase in quality-related damages.
b)    Market-related damages identified at the market level, stood at 0.49% of total sales. This is within the KPI threshold of 0.50%, reflecting reasonable control at the post-production stage, although continued vigilance is necessary to maintain performance.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

   NB. Oven-related damages (333 loaves) & slicer related damages (501) were excluded from the analysis.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should strengthen end-to-end quality control measures across all stages production, packing, and market dispatch to ensure early detection of defects and significantly reduce the occurrence of damages
attributes.effect:
•    Production damages rate suggests the need for tighter operational controls during the production process to avoid and reduce further damages at production level.
•    While market damages at 0.49% remain within the acceptable KPI threshold, they still represent a significant volume of loss (2,231 loaves) that could impact profitability and customer satisfaction if not consistently managed.

value:
•    During the review period, 501 loaves were not recorded as oven damages but were affected due to a slicing machine malfunction.
•    The slicer breakdown took considerable time to be repaired, which delayed the slicing process and disrupted production flow.
•    The deduction noted were as a result of negligence by workers.
•    We will ensure production of good quality bread, for us to minimize production damages.

•    In the prior audit date 2nd May 2025, it was noted that;      
a)    Production damages were 0.225% of the total production,
b)    Market damages were 0.48% of the total sales.
Slightly above-target production damages (0.204%) were found, mostly from oven and slicer malfunctions. Market damages were within limits.
Tighter quality controls and swift equipment repair are necessary to prevent further losses.
Operations/Production Department
To assess the rate of bread damages from production and market handling.

attributes.title: Damages sent to Ingredients’ Balance Analysis
attributes.description:
•    An audit verification was carried out on 11th June 2025 to confirm that all bread damages reported as transferred to the Ingredients Department were either physically present or properly recorded in accordance with established procedures.
•    The audit identified inconsistencies in record-keeping during the review period, where reported bread damages sent to the ingredients department exceeded the actual physical damages available at the branch over multiple days. This recurring pattern points to potential gaps in documentation accuracy or the presence of unaccounted sources of damage that were not properly recorded.
attributes.recommendation: •    Routine physical verification of damaged bread by the Operations Manager should be enhanced to ensure timely reconciliation and prevent the accumulation of unreconciled damage quantities.
attributes.effect: The fact that damages reported as sent to the Ingredients Department exceeded both the calculated and physically verified balances over several days suggests potential risks of: Unrecorded damages or diversions, Inadequate reconciliation practices, Or weak controls in damages.

value:
•    Previous damage records were found to be unreliable; however, corrective measures have now been implemented to enhance the accuracy and reliability of record-keeping.
•    Going forward, all records will be properly maintained, and appropriate controls will be enforced to monitor and manage bread damages effectively.

•    There were some oven damages which were not captured in the damage book but it has been rectified.
•    Manager has been advised to ensure proper accountability of all damages.
•    In the previous audit report, it was observed that there was  excess damages balance sent to the Ingredients department to the tune of 20.45kgs
Previous
Audit revealed inconsistencies where reported damage exceeded physically verified figures, indicating gaps in documentation.
Enhanced reconciliation and routine damage verification were recommended.
Operations/Production Department
To verify that bread damages transferred to the Ingredients Department are accurately recorded and properly transferred.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    An evaluation was carried out to determine how effectively human resources are being utilized in the production department, with emphasis on whether production staff are achieving the company’s benchmark of 4.5 production bags per worker, as specified in the operational policy.
•    The analysis revealed that production efficiency was at 4.42 per production worker, which was slightly below  the standard rate of 4.5 bags as seen in the summary below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Implementation of a preventive maintenance schedule for critical production equipment like ovens and slicers is necessary to minimize breakdowns and production disruptions.
attributes.effect: •    Continued inefficiencies could increase operational costs and hinder the branch’s ability to meet production targets and customer demand.

value:
•    Instances of oven breakdown and slicer machine malfunctions negatively impacted overall production efficiency.
•    However, with active monitoring and follow-ups now in place, we are committed to ensuring that production targets and efficiencies are consistently achieved.
•    Instances of oven breakdown and slicer machine malfunctions negatively impacted overall production efficiency.
•    The previous audit report indicated a production efficiency of 4.45 bags per production worker.
Efficiency was slightly below target (4.42). Equipment downtime contributed to reduced output.
Preventive maintenance and effective staff deployment were suggested to improve efficiency.
Operations/Production Department
To measure if production workers meet the expected output benchmark of 4.5 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
•    An assessment was conducted to evaluate the efficiency of packers in the slicing section, aiming to determine if they met the company’s standard of 97 crates per packer.
•    The analysis covered the period from 12th  May 2025 to 11th June 2025 and revealed that the packing efficiency was slightly above the target, as summarized below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management to review packer staffing periodically to align with production volume and efficiency targets, ensuring neither understaffing nor overstaffing occurs.
attributes.effect: •    The efficiency achieved suggests good workforce productivity and potentially optimized packing processes.

value: •    We shall do monitoring and follow up to ensure that the efficiency is attained at all time while maintaining the current controls in place.
•    We are pushing the newly inducted members to work on their speed and meet the expected target.
•    The previous audit report indicated a packing efficiency of 96.01 crates per packer.
Packing efficiency slightly exceeded the target (98.07), indicating good productivity.
Maintain current staffing controls and continue performance monitoring.
Operations/Production Department
To determine if packing staff met the KPI of 97 crates per packer.

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
•    A spot check was carried out at the Mini Shop on 11th June 2025, to confirm that all bread stocked for sale was accurately recorded and that the reported sales were fully reconciled with the collections made via the designated Mpesa pay bill number. The Mini Shop operates under a cashless policy.
•    The audit identified an excess amount of Kshs 69, which staff explained was from a customer who had overpaid but had not yet claimed their bread. Due to the absence of supporting transactional evidence at the time of the audit, we requested a reconciliation at the end of the day to verify whether the amount was subsequently claimed. Below is a summary of the audit findings:
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure daily end-of-day reconciliations are conducted between physical stock movement, recorded sales and Mpesa collections and the reconciliation done should tally
attributes.effect:
•    The unexplained excess of Kshs 69, although minor, highlights a gap in transactional documentation and control over sales collections.
•     The absence of supporting documentation for the overpayment exposes the operation to risks of revenue misstatement, customer disputes, or potential misappropriation.

value:
•    Controls in place shall be maintained.
•    However, daily reconciliation and explanation of the balances if any shall be emphasized
•    Controls in place are effective to be maintained
•    In the prior audit report, there was a shortfall of Kshs 158.04, due to bread replacements done before the breads with issues were brought to the minishop

A small difference of Kshs 69 was noticed, caused by an unclaimed overpayment. However, by the end of the day, this amount had been claimed, and the final reconciliation showed only minor differences due to transaction charges.
Daily reconciliation and better documentation are necessary to avoid customer disputes and to ensure no variances between the sales  and  the amounts received
Operations/Production Department
To verify accuracy of mini shop sales and reconcile Mpesa receipts with actual bread sold.

attributes.title: Vehicles Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review was conducted on the branch of vehicles’ fuel consumption to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the month of May 2025
Finding:
•    Other Route vehicle’s fuel consumption was within the set standard except for Tassia route which had an overconsumption as detailed  below:
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management Should ensure that any overconsumption is either justified, utilized, or deducted from the following day's allocation to prevent balance buildup.
attributes.effect:
•    The overconsumption of fuel on the Tassia route suggests a potential inefficiency in vehicle operation
•    Consistent deviations from standard fuel consumption rates can reflect poorly on internal controls over resource utilization.

value:
•    We shall continue issuing fuel according to kms covered.
•    The overconsumption in Tassia route will be utilized in the following days
There will be a follow up and recovery will be done to ensure efficiency is optimal.
Tassia route showed overconsumption. Other routes were within limits.
Excess to be accounted for in subsequent days. Monitoring of fuel usage continues.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate if fuel usage by delivery vehicles aligns with distance covered.

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    A review of the debtors’ balances as of 3rd June 2025 was conducted to determine if there were cases of outstanding balances at the branch that could result in bad debts.
•  We focused mainly on auditable accounts with unpaid balances, especially from clients who hadn’t received supplies in the following days. Dormant institutions were also reviewed. Priority was given to debts with medium to high credit risk, such as missing security deposits or noted supply gaps. The accounts below were flagged, and sales reps provided the following updates.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch management and sales team should maintain strict debt management controls to prevent overdue balances from accumulating.
attributes.effect: •    Debt management within the branch is well controlled, with most customers having adequate security deposits.

value: •    We shall liaise with the sales team to ensure timely debt collection to facilitate supply.
The sales team is working hard to make sure all debts are fully paid.

A review of debtors’ balances was carried out to identify any accounts at risk of turning into bad debts. The review focused on clients with unpaid balances, especially those who had not received supplies recently, as well as dormant institutions.

The review found Kshs 72,356.00 in outstanding balances across five key accounts. Some were supported by security deposits, while others remain at risk and require active recovery efforts. Sales reps have shared follow-up plans to help mitigate potential losses.
Sales Department
To review outstanding debts and assess credit risk exposure.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis.
attributes.description:
•    We evaluated the generator's fuel consumption from 1st June 2025 to 12th June 2025 to assess its efficiency and ensure it operated within expected parameters.
•    Based on the collected data, the results were deemed reasonable and consistent with the operational standards for this period as seen below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The existing controls are effective and should be strengthened to ensure fuel consumption remains within reasonable limits and that the physical fuel balance is accurately recorded.
attributes.effect: •    The minor variance between the manager’s records and the system records suggests slight inconsistencies, which could be due to calibration issues or recording errors.

value: •    Calibration issue shall be raised for KAF to rectify.

•    We will ensure there is a follow up with the KAF team. 
•    Fuel purchase and fuel consumption are mainly controlled by fleet controller.
•    In the previous audit, analysis was done on the generator fuel consumption for a period of 30 days from 1st April 25 to 30th April 2025 which revealed a consumption of 23.697 liters/hour.
Minor discrepancies noted between system and manual logs, possibly due to calibration issues.
Raise issue with KAF for calibration and maintain effective fuel usage tracking.
Transport/Fleet Department
To assess generator fuel use and verify its alignment with recorded operating hours.
